title-group.article-title: Extranodal Extension Improves AJCC-8 Accuracy in HPV+ Oropharyngeal Cancer in a High-Risk Population

article-meta.aff: 1University of Kentucky College of Medicine, Lexington Kentucky, USA
2University of Kentucky, Department of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery, Lexington, Kentucky, USA
3University of KwaZulu-Natal, Department of Otorhinolaryngology, Durban, South Africa
4Medical University of South Carolina, Department of Otolaryngology, Charleston, South Carolina, USA.

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Alexandra Eva Kejner, MD, FACS, Associate Professor, Division of Head and Neck Surgical Oncology and Microvascular Reconstruction, Department of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery, Medical University of South Carolina, 135 Rutledge Avenue, Rutledge Tower, MSC 550, Charleston, SC 29425, alexkejner@gmail.com

fn.p: Conflicts of Interest: AEK has a completed research grant through Vioptix Inc.

sec.title: Objectives:
sec.p: The American Joint Committee on Cancer’s 8th edition (AJCC-8) separates oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas (OPSCCs) into human papillomavirus-positive (HPV+) tumors and HPV-negative tumors. While AJCC-8 improves prognostic prediction for survival for the majority of HPV+ OPSCC, outliers are still encountered. The goal of this manuscript is to validate the AJCC-8 as a better metric of survivability over AJCC-7 in a historically under-served rural population with confounding variables such as tobacco use, alcohol consumption, and poor healthcare access, and to analyze the role of extranodal extension (ENE) in this population.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Compared to AJCC-7, AJCC-8 had a higher odds ratio (OR) of predicting mortality of stage IV HPV+ OPSCCs versus stages I–III. On multivariate analysis, HPV+ OPSCCs with ENE had a higher OR of mortality compared to ENE- OPSCCs. Additionally, HPV+ OPSCC patients with a Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI) > 3 had a higher OR of mortality compared to those with a CCI<=3. Patients with Medicaid/self-pay status had higher OR of mortality compared to those with private insurance/Medicare. Finally, patients from rural populations had a higher OR of presenting with stage IV disease, a CCI>3, and Medicaid/self-pay status.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Despite not being a discrete part of the AJCC-8 staging rubric, ENE was found to have a significant impact on mortality among this population while tobacco use had no effect. Rural patients were more likely to present with stage IV disease, CCI>3, and Medicaid/self-pay status. Stage IV disease was also associated with higher OR of mortality.

abstract.title: Lay Summary:
abstract.p: This study evaluates the AJCC-8 staging criteria for oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas in a high-risk population with risk factors that historically worsen survival outcomes. It additionally evaluates extranodal extension as a prognostic factor for these tumors.
